intro: Moricandia dumosa, commonly known as desert mustards, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of the western United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other mustard plants. The plant is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. Its leaves are typically lobed and covered in a fine layer of white, powdery wax, which helps reduce water loss in its dry habitat. Moricandia dumosa is often found in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to thrive in low-nutrient environments.
